SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: ROBERT WHITFIELD HUSTON

2. Your address: Melfort Nursery Home

3. Date: March 1954

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   PERTH COUNTY, ONT.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   SAMUEL HUSTON, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   1896

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Went to Manitoba in 1888 - Pilot Mound - taught school - went to Normal School in 1892 in Wpg after teaching on permit.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   18 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Father had died - farm rented - learned teaching at a model school or Stratford - salaries better in West - about $500 per year.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Father much interested - one of my sisters had married a homesteader at Beulah. The name Beulah arose from the fact that when a name was being considered there were two farmers conservative and two Liberals; instead of fighting over "Blake" or "Macdonald" the wives suggested Beulah - the title of a book (novel) which was being read in the community.
    Got information about West in materials in model school at Stratford.
1. Your full name: Robert Whitefield Houston

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Went to Manitoba in 1888 - Pilot Mound - taught school - went to Normal School in 1892 in Winnipeg after teaching on farms.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.) I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Father had died - farm rented - claimed teaching at a model school in Stratford - valaries better in West - about $500 per year.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) My father much interested - one of my sisters had married a homesteader at Beulah. Beulah arose from the fact that when a man whose dairy surrendered there were two farmers (one and two kilowatts instead of eighty over "Blake" or Macdonald" the unused suggested Beulah - the title of a book (name) which was being read in the community.

For information about West in materialism model school of Stratford.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?
   By self—bought came with Mr. Beatty from St. Mary's—a store keeper.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   C.P.R. to Pilot Mound.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other exciting events, etc.)
   Surprised at first sight of an ox pulling a sleigh near Winnipeg—very few oxen in Ontario at that time.
   Taught near Pilot Mound for about six years.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Beaver Hills—25 mi NW Yorkton—near Theodore 1896—6 mo. school teaching—then to Hamona school for 5½ years—until 1909—bought a ¼ near Hamona school.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   SW 32-37-24 W3 near Luseland in 1909—stayed until 1917 when sold place for $4000. & got some good crops off it.
   Spring 1919 went to B.C. worked on poultry farms—stayed 4 years. Came back to Spy Hill in 1923 at time of organizing Wheat Pool—was elected as a delegate (still had land in district) Went to Yankton before daylight.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Tried twice to go to Yankton to hear him speak. Tried buying an extra theatre but not too successful. Sapino protested when collection plate started—claiming he had insisted on no collections at any of his meetings.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

C.P.R. to Plo / Newland

14. What incidents of the journey? What do you remember (people you met on the train, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other events)?

Surprised at first sight of an ox pulling a sleigh near Winnipeg - very few seen in Ontario at that time.

Stayed near Pilot Mound for about nine years.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Blaineville - 25 mi. from Yorkton - near Meadow Lake

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Harmonia school - until 1909 - bought a ¼ near Harmonia school

17. Mention any other interesting facts:

School closed off in 1879 went to B.C. until 1917 when sold place for $4000. Aged home

Spring 1917 went to B.C. until 1923 or 1924 came back to Spy Well in 1923 or 1924 (not sure)

Urban Paul was elected as a delegate to found town (no day job)

Land in district

18. Any other comments:

To go to school & hear him speak. Tried to raise an extra head but not so successful.

Sapir promoted when election held started planning to hold meeting on zoo collection or any of his meeting.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Bachelor.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Brother SAMUEL WESLEY went to Winnipeg - worked in hardware store - 4 years younger.
Sister LAURA ETHEL ("Lottie") FRASER - her daughter is Mrs. Stanley Rands, Regina.
Youngest brother enlisted in S.A. war and was killed in war.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Brother S.W. bought farm near Battleford in spring of 1917. Was M.L.A. - died in 1932. He had a daughter Mrs. Fred Thrower, Vancouver.
son son Mr. Harold Huston, Lacombe, Alta.
Mr. Harold Huston, Banff.

Sister LAURA ETHEL (Ethel) RAUSER-HEWITT worked in homesteads for 4 years.

Sister LAURA STANLEY (Rand) RAUSER was a daughter in Miss Stanley, Rand, Regina.

Youngest child was killed in war.

After this S.W. bought farm near Battleford in vicinity of 1917. Also M.C.A. died in 1932. He had a daughter Mrs. Fred Johnson, Karrsville, Alta.

Mr. Harold Hilton, Bixby, Okl.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Salvador - 7 mi from Ried.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).
   But got rural supplies from Huffnagel who had 2 S.A. scripts & one had a general store - very good & very low prices.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   From start & Salvador - munic. offices here.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.
   No. One lady said "Trouble with Eaton's cat. - everyone knows what you pay" - friend said "well at least everyone knows you paid for it."

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Salvador East & Salvador West - 2 companies in district.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Improved health in West was big reason for decision. Went to B.C. for winter first in 1916.
